page.title: 11Quaker Conference Centre
page.content: Charney Manor (which was mentioned in the Domesday Book) has had many owners. In 1906 it was restored from its delapidated state,and in 1948 was bought by a group of Oxford Quakers led by Henry Gillett. They presented it to the Society of Friends for use as "a place where people might come to find peace of mind,friendliness & relaxation".Now a Charitable Trust, Charney Manor is developing its role as a Quaker House & Conference Centre. There are regular meetings for worship in the Solar with its open timber work ceiling.The residential conference centre is open to all denominations. Charitable work includes training groups e.g.Oxfam & Samaritans. The establishment is aided by the William Allen Society based in London and the Friends of Charney Manor who give help and raise funds when necessary.
